quote.#text: National Mental Health No Stigma Week

official-title.#text: Expressing support for designation of the first full week of May as

committee-name.#text: Committee on Oversight and Government Reform

cosponsor.#text: Mr. Gary G. Miller of California
Ms. Linda T. Sánchez of California

cosponsor.#tail: ) submitted the following resolution; which was referred to the

quote.#text: National Mental Health No Stigma Week

text.#text:
Whereas it is in the best interest of the United States to increase awareness regarding the
			 negative stigma associated with mental illness;
Whereas stigma is a very real problem for people who have a mental illness;

Whereas every person needs and deserves to feel a sense of belonging, and not be excluded or
			 ostracized;

Whereas the most formidable obstacle to future progress in the area of mental health is stigma, and
			 today, the United States has the power to tear down that obstacle;

Whereas some of the harmful effects of stigma include trying to pretend nothing is wrong, refusal
			 to seek treatment, rejection by family and friends, work or school
			 problems or discrimination, difficulty finding housing, being subjected to
			 physical violence or harassment, and inadequate health insurance coverage
			 of mental illnesses;

Whereas approximately 20 percent of youth ages 13 to 18 and approximately 13 percent of those ages
			 8 to 15 experience severe mental disorders in a given year;
Whereas despite civil rights laws, such as the

Whereas according to the California Mental Health Services Oversight and Accountability
			 Commission’s report of 2007, a public education campaign can improve the
			 public’s awareness of unmet needs and reduce the harmful effects of stigma
			 and discrimination; and

quote.#text: National Mental Health No Stigma Week

text.#text: Whereas the first full week of May would be an appropriate week to designate as

{http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/}title.#text: 113 HRES 572 IH: Expressing support for designation of the first full week of May as “National Mental Health No Stigma Week”.
